captions.text:
CHRIS HARRIS: To recap quickly,
Dan did a rally last

And I did a similar event in
January, a single-venue rally

But this was the big one,
the Wye Dean, our

A classic forest event with
big things to hit.

Luckily, it's right on my
doorstep, so if we shunted, we

The beauty of the Wye Dean
is it's on my doorstep.

So I don't need to go and wait
around in service at home.

He's sitting on the
naughty stool.

I'm sitting on the
normal stool.

Then we get to just go outside,
leave the family, get

in the car, and drive down to
service, which is about four

And then we get to compete on,
what everyone is telling me,

is one of the most demanding
gravel or forest

A little bit nervous because

But hopefully, the
fog will be gone.

And hopefully, Dan will
start to say a bit

But we passed after
a few tweaks.

And then it was the same as
all motorsport, really.

Lots of chatting and mooching
around the place, looking at

And 5 right, half long
into hairpin left.
DAN: Told you you would be.

6 right here, and slowing
into square right.

170, [INAUDIBLE] through posts
and 3 right into 1 left.

CHRIS HARRIS: Sorry,
I wasn't on it.

CHRIS HARRIS: Dan read
the notes really

And we exercised caution for
all the obvious reasons.

Neil was out on the stage, and
he really captured the spirit

Just look at some
of these cars.

CHRIS HARRIS: The plan
for Stage Two was to

This nearly caused us a few
problems, but letting the car
move around was a huge buzz.

DAN: 6 right over
bumps and turn.

So turn hairpin left
at the bottom.

CHRIS HARRIS: And little did we
know it, but that was the

By the time we reached Stage
Three, the motor was leaking

oil from the sump,
and we were out.

So before we explain what
happened to the 325, here's

some more footage of
cars being driven

For me, this is fundamental
motorsport,

Right, OK, this is what
happened then.

The first stage,
we went slowly.

But we finished, and
we were euphoric.

We then got the road route
slightly wrong.

And Dan will explain himself
in a minute.

And then I stopped, just to
adjust the water jets at the

beginning of third stage, before
the start of the third

stage, and noticed a large pool
of a dark, treacle-like

liquid, underneath the engine,
on top of the sump guard.
This turned out to be oil.

And on closer inspection,
there was

So that was kind of
the end of it.

And I have hugely mixed emotions
at the moment.

I'm angry, because it's not
often a journalist spends his
And today cost a few quid.

So incidentally, I'm thinking,
that pisses me off.

I didn't get my value
out of it.

Whatever it was, 11 stage
miles for a grand.

But when I was in the car and
the notes were flowing and it

was working, it felt
really good.
But the car was just mega-fun.

I'm now more convinced than I
was at the start that that's

It's much slower than all
the quick 1400 cars.

But then, it's worth very
little, and most corners are
sideways if you want to be.

So the faith is still
there in the BMW.

I don't know how we got through
a massive sump guard

and bent the sump, but
it was a big impact.

And no doubt, we'll see it on
the video around about now.

Three weeks later, I can now
tell you what happened to the

A stone became wedged
between the sump

We hit that bump, and it forced
a chunk of the sump

back into the pan, which
was luckily caught

It ran low on oil, but it's
still absolutely fine now.

But we're planning another car
now, faster and more sideways.

title: The Wye Dean rally in a Ratty BMW 325i - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS

comments.text: Wasn't expecting to see that FN2 but cool!﻿
comments.author: MattT2k9

comments.text:
I think I need to show you people what a REAL "ratty" car looks like, Up 
here in the Rust Belt, this is just starting to show its age a bit.
And what do you mean at breakfast "these are our driving positions"? In the 
car, he's sitting on the left...
Notice you got a new steering wheel too? I thought the old one looked 
bigger than it should be for a race car.
Just out of curiosity, do AWD and RWD cars compete in different classes? 
Seems like a big advantage there.﻿
comments.author: justforever96

comments.text:
Stone between the sump and the sump guard: put a foam pad between to keep 
the stones out. But make sure you have a big enough oil cooler because 
there will be even less airflow around the sump.﻿

comments.author: Ford RS

comments.text:
Think of it this way: What if you hadn't realized the oil was leaking? If 
you'd have just went for the 3rd stage you'd have got five hundred meters 
and then the engine cuts, you check to see what's happened, see there's no 
oil and the motor is totally ruined, you might as well just trash it all 
together. At least now you only need to fix the leakage and fill it up with 
oil and you have a perfectly working toy again!﻿

comments.author: qwasd0r

comments.text:
Chris some tips for You:
The two biggest problem with E30s are the rear suspension and the 
front/rear weight distribution. 
With the rear suspension theres not much you can do, but if you'd like to 
make the car less nose-heavy you should put an M52B28 single vanos engine 
inside. Its aluminium block is 28kg lighter right where it matters: on the 
front axle, and it also has more power, 193hp as stock. If you put an 
M50TUB25 single vanos air intake throttle body ecu afm so basically 
everything from an M50TUB25 engine onto the M52B28 and remap the M50's 
Bosch 413 Ecu to give the more fuel needed for the extra 300cm3 you'll get 
230hp easily and the whole thing would cost less than 500GBP. You will be 
able to use the existing gearbox clutch flywheel, starter motor (only if 
the flywheel is kept) propshaft, cooling system, (for using the oil cooling 
of the 325i you'll need an oil filter house from an S50engine but that 
still isn't expensive) the rear part of the exhaust, etc. Btw you'll need 
an E34 M50 oil pan and and oil pump intake pipe.
Benefits? More power, more low-end torque which is useful using a gearbox 
like yours, less weight (on the front!), less ability to lose oil pressure 
when cornering hard or changing direction, easily remappable (let's say 
home-remappable) Bosch 413 ecu...
That's the best way forward! Keep going! ;)﻿

comments.author: AnHRTBus

comments.text:
The Golf R would be awesome but possibly too expensive to be reasonable to 
run.  I have no idea how many they got in the UK, but here the R32 
regardless of which Gen it is) is a very "collectible" car.  A MKII Syncro 
16V Golf would be awesome too and maybe more plentiful (I'm jealous) over 
there.  A Celica All-Trac would be amazing.  There's one here in Oregon 
where I live and race (MKII Golf) and it's probably as close to a real 
Group B car as I'm ever going to see on person, on track.  

+qwkutiub That's likely an easy fix.  You just replace it with a locked 
50/50 unit (in fact it's just a set of cardanan/U-joints or a biased unit 
for more rear application.  I've payed around with a lot of Diffs and LSD's 
and you can REALLY easily build a biased unit by just adding washers to the 
clutch springs on one side and none on the other to make the LSD "tighter" 
on one side then the other.  Usually you wouldn't do this because you want 
even distribution side to side, but if it's oriented N/S then you just have 
either front or rear bias.  I know the R diff is likely not that easy to 
mod, and as I said above I don;t know how plentiful Golf R's are in the UK 
or how much he wants to spend to tear apart a desirable road car to beat on 
it as a rally car.  A MKII Golf 16V Syncro might be more plentiful and 
would be an awesome chassis with MUCH cheaper and easier to do yourself 
mods.
